comments.commentBody: Would this disqualify him from getting a security clearance?
It was sarcasm.  We are laughing at you lefties over this.  Wow.
Comey said there was "no evidence" that HRC's server was hacked.
A joke? If you are running for president and inviting Russia to commit espionage against the US that you are unfit to be president. And he wasn't joking.

Do you think they are same category issues?

honestly?

One is one party's internal policy problem, other one literally inviting a rival nation spy in the USA.

These things are equal for you.

Except that the DNC didn't write the emails.  Putin and Wikileaks faked them. The evidence is clear. Time for the NY Times to apologize to Clinton and the DNC for trashing them without investigating the story first.
Actually, it makes it crystal clear
Man, dirty tricks from the DNC, dirty talk from Trump.  Kinda makes it hard to know who to vote for.

This is not a real issue?

Hillary Clinton Benghazi and email were real issue, but a guy who will be a candidate calling arch rival of USA to meddle with our internal politics and national security is not a real issue.

Do you really know the text book definition of Bias?
Please, please, PLEASE, NYT: stop publishing these stories. The more press Trump gets, the better it is for his campaign. This is not real news anymore. Let's focus on the issues, please.
Hillary might be in trouble.  But if Trunp is elected we are ALL in trouble.
Trump should be on the FBI's watch list. The man is dangerous.
I agree completely but believe there is more than NPD going on, probably an additional PD and certainly mild to moderate cognitive impairment.
Is there anyone left out there who does not think Donald Trump is dangerous?

Charles the court let the first 3 off, the next 3 would probably have gotten off as well. the DA dropped their case as they realized they didn't have a case.  Maybe it is a giant conspiracy or maybe they were just innocent.  Having looked at the details of the Michael Brown case he seemed to have attacked a police officer and the police officer defended himself with justifiable force.  I think the justice department agrees, so when you put all of these cases as something that would suggest racism, I feel you are projecting your racism.   Your anger and what you said in this column will lead to more violence not less, so please consider that as you vent.
I'm with you Charles. So disgusted. So disheartened. Not a great outlook for our country that we would so like to love and support. Painful.

Even a disinterested observer might be concerned about how someone could be put into a police van in a reasonable state of health  and arrive at the station near death. Or maybe what really matters is whether this was someone  important enough for us to be concerned about.

Charles always writes and speaks very eloquently on most subjects, and this is no exception. As was mentioned in some of the other comments, this issue not only disgusts blacks but also many whites (like myself). When combined with the hateful rhetoric from the Republican nominee and his cronies, this paints a very sad portrait of what the US has become. Many will argue that many of the individuals involve were not exhibiting exemplary behavior, but all one needs to look at is the case of Senator Tim Scott (see the URL below) to see what a dire situation we are in between the cops and the Black community at large.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/on-the-senate-floor-black-gop-se...
2000 shootings not murders

Note what Mr. Blow doesn't get angry at.  He doesn't get angry at the massive rise in the shooting deaths in Chicago, where I think there have already been 2000 murders this year, mostly blacks by other blacks.  He doesn't get angry at the percentage of black babies born out of wedlock - 70% (if you can believe that).  He doesn't get mad when Michael Ferguson assaults a shop owner while stealing; and he doesn't get angry that the lie which started the Ferguson riots (arms up, don't shoot) results in the looting of many Asian-owned businesses.  He also doesn't get angry when the Baltimore prosecutor trumps up murder charges against the police officers involved in the Gray death, three of whom were black.  (Black police officers' lives don't matter to Mr. Blow apparently.)  No, Mr. Blow mainly gets angry when a Republican uses the phrase "law and order" which has also now apparently become a dog whistle for white supremacists according to Mr. Blow.

The death of any unarmed American either in the custody of law enforcement or at the hands of law enforcement needs to be investigated by the next higher level of government and the decision to prosecute or not to prosecute should be made jointly by that higher level and the next higher level of government. Any resulting trial should be conducted at no lower than state court level.

For example, the death of Freddie Gray in police custody should have been investigated by the state of Maryland and the decision to prosecute or not to prosecute should have been a joint decision by the state of Maryland and the U.S. Dept. of Justice. The trials should have been under the auspices of the state.

Local prosecutors and local courts have disqualified themselves as agents of justice in these death cases.

Mr. Blow, I am so sad to read the feelings you have expressed. The justice system is not equipped to address the problems cited by you and the eminent Mr. Baldwin, for all kinds of reasons. When the medical examiner says a death is a "homicide", this means that it was the result of human agency, i.e., not necessarily criminality. In the rush to charge these suspects, the state apparently did not do adequate analysis of the evidence or applicable statutes. If there is acquittal after acquittal, whether by jury or bench (another factor to take into account in charging  is what kind of trial defense might likely demand and why), there is a problem with the state's proof. This exacerbates the problem of responding properly to the conduct alleged here. Whatever the justice system does wrong--and it does plenty--it will surely make worse mistakes if it acts in the heat of the twenty-four-hour news cycle.

Excellent and perceptive comment. Education is not only the key to productive lives; it is also the key to creating and maintaining the bonds of community as it cultivates an understanding of what we share, not only what divides us.

Yes, the fact is that most police shooting are indeed justified.  But the problem is that our militarised police quickly escalate encounters with the public, especially black Americans, use force all too often, and kill far too many people each DAY.  Of those killed, most are justified shootings, but the absolute number of unjustified shootings in the US is staggering.  Without accountability and arrests of officers who abuse their positions of power or are negligent in their actions, this sad situation will continue, or even worsen.  At least, either the driver or the officer who failed to put the prisoner in restraints in the vehicle were negligent, but now they get off scott free.

I point out that a black judge presided over the trials and acquittals of three officers charged over the Freddie Gray incident and found them innocent on all counts. The case against the police officers was very weak from the start, so weak that they probably shouldn't even have been charged. The charges against the remaining officers were equally weak and the prosecutor realized the futility of pressing on and dropped them. Rage all you want - I think the acquittals were just and there was no sense in proceeding to trial against the remaining officers.

The fact is most police shootings are justified, regardless of race, and that's why few officers are charged and even fewer convicted.

Try young, exuberant and inexperienced instead of acting as though this prosecutor overcharged with malice.  Why not give prosecutors the benefit of the doubt?  You expect us to do that for the police.

coroner's homicide means man-caused, vs natural causes or tree- falling pr meteor strike

coroner is not a rand jury

grand jury 'homicide' is diff

and then the petite jury, where the charges are heard, is diff still

Something you are obviously unaware of: not all homicides are a crime, particularly when there is a lack of criminal intent.

Do a little reading outside of these pages.
Let me get this straight: the coroner ruled it a homicide and no one was convicted? How can that be? You are right: something is very wrong in America.

I don't know what to say so I'll just use the words Chris Christie used while being interviewed during the Republican Convention. "Police should ALWAYS (emphasis mine) be given the benefit of the doubt." Running to be Mr. Trump's Attorney General, obviously.

I've seen 6 comments so far. I'm waiting for the usual string that:
1) blame the black community for having a higher rate of criminality (ignoring such facts as whites using more drugs but getting stopped, searched, and arrested less often, etc.)
2) say that the problem is people not obeying the police (ignoring guys like Charles Kinsey, mental health caregiver, shot while lying on the ground with his hands in the air)
3) say that police shoot more whites than blacks (true in total numbers, but as a percentage, blacks are 2.5 times more likely than whites to be shot by police).
Today I'm not at the screaming place as much as the vomiting place.

As a white person who has watched this system from all angles for most of my personal and professional life, I can tell you it's the system and racism is built into it. The price of admission for minorities who want to become part of the system is that they have to go along with it.

If there had not been so many Black people involved in this case, on all sides, no one would have even been indicted, as is the usual procedure.

My hat is off to Black people who join the "justice" system in hopes of gradually changing it. If you think it's tough being a cop, try being a Black cop.
And let's not forget there are many black cops who are corrupt as well. Not all cops are white.

The judge was black as well. Charles is not satisfied, he doesn't believe in law, he wants a lynch mob and a race war. But I can bet he himself lives in a safe nice Neighbourhood, so it doesn't matter to him that the race war he incites will burn down poor communities and push them even further down. He should direct his rage at the Baltimore mayor and the prosecutor Mosby who overcharged without evidence in order to score political brownie points.

Let's get this right. Half of the cops were black. The attorney general is black. The city council is majority black. The mayor is black. In spite of all of this some people actually have the nerve (stupidity?) to call this event RACIAL?
Yup:  Thank you.
Thank you Charles.
